biblioentry.title: What is HDF5?
biblioentry.bibliomisc: Concise description about HDF5 capabilities and its differences from earlier versions (HDF4)

biblioentry.title: Introduction to HDF5
biblioentry.bibliomisc: Introduction to the HDF5 data model and programming model

biblioentry.title: The HDF5 table programming model
biblioentry.bibliomisc: Examples on using HDF5 tables with the C API

biblioentry.title: zlib. A Massively Spiffy Yet Delicately Unobtrusive Compression Library
biblioentry.bibliomisc: A standard library for compression purposes

biblioentry.title: Objectify. On the 'Pythonic' treatment of XML documents as objects(II)
biblioentry.bibliomisc: Article describing XML Objectify, a Python module that allows working with XML documents as Python objects. Some of the ideas presented here are used in PyTables

biblioentry.title: Cython. A language that makes writing C extensions for the Python language as easy as Python itself
NetCDF. Network Common Data Form
biblioentry.bibliomisc: An interface for array-oriented data access and a library that provides an implementation of the interface

biblioentry.title: NetCDF-4. Network Common Data Form version 4
biblioentry.bibliomisc: Merging the NetCDF and HDF5 Libraries

biblioentry.title: NumPy. Scientific Computing with Numerical Python
biblioentry.bibliomisc: The latest and most powerful re-implementation of Numeric to date. It implements all the features that can be found in Numeric and numarray, plus a bunch of new others. In general, it is more efficient as well

biblioentry.title: Numerical Python
biblioentry.bibliomisc: Package to speed-up arithmetic operations on arrays of numbers

biblioentry.title: Numarray
biblioentry.bibliomisc: Reimplementation of Numeric which adds the ability to efficiently manipulate large numeric arrays in ways similar to Matlab and IDL. Among others, Numarray provides the record array extension

biblioentry.title: Numexpr. Fast evaluation of array expressions by using a vector-based virtual machine
biblioentry.bibliomisc: It is an enhaced computing kernel that is generally faster (between 1x and 10x, depending on the kind of operations) than NumPy at evaluating complex array expressions

biblioentry.title: LZO. A data compression library which is suitable for data de-/compression in real-time
biblioentry.bibliomisc: It offers pretty fast compression and decompression with reasonable compression ratio

biblioentry.title: bzip2. A high performance lossless compressor
biblioentry.bibliomisc: It offers very high compression ratios within reasonable times

biblioentry.title: Blosc. A blocking, shuffling and loss-less compression library
biblioentry.bibliomisc: A compressor designed to transmit data from memory to CPU (and back) faster than a plain memcpy()

biblioentry.title: Psyco. A Python specializing compiler
biblioentry.bibliomisc: Run existing Python software faster, with no change in your source

biblioentry.title: Scientific Python
biblioentry.bibliomisc: Collection of Python modules useful for scientific computing

biblioentry.title: SciPy. Scientific tools for Python
biblioentry.bibliomisc: SciPy supplements the popular Numeric module, gathering a variety of high level science and engineering modules together as a single package

biblioentry.title: Optimization of file openings in PyTables
biblioentry.bibliomisc: This document explores the savings of the opening process in terms of both CPU time and memory, due to the adoption of a LRU cache for the nodes in the object tree

biblioentry.title: ViTables. A GUI for PyTables/HDF5 files
biblioentry.bibliomisc: It is a graphical tool for browsing and editing files in both PyTables and HDF5 formats

biblioentry.title: GnuWin32. GNU (and other) tools ported to Win32
biblioentry.bibliomisc: GnuWin32 provides native Win32-versions of GNU tools, or tools with a similar open source licence

biblioentry.title: OPSI: The indexing system of PyTables 2 Professional Edition
biblioentry.bibliomisc: Exhaustive description and benchmarks about the indexing engine that comes with PyTables Pro
